history.content: Ideally, professors who have seen you work before are the strongest recommenders. So, you should ask professors that you work with and interact with on a deeper level than a student-teacher interaction. While professors who taught you and see you at OH likely would know your intellectual curiosity, they have no idea what working with you would be like. People typically ask for recommendations from professors they've done research with or are on course staff with.

How well do professors need to know students to write letters of recommendations?

I ask this because I am a student who attends office hours for almost all my professors (often the only one in OH too), and I believe I interact plenty with my courses; however, I can't really imagine that my professors "know" me "enough" through this to write a letter of recommendation. Granted, I've had minimal experience in utilizing or gaining letters of recommendation, so I do not know the level of depth letters of recommendations needed, especially for undergrad research programs. 

As another question, if I recognize a professor as someone who I could potentially ask for a letter of recommendation for future programs, should I ask them for a letter as soon as my main interactions with them stop (Ie. right after a course ends in the case that a professor forgets about me later when I'll need letters of rec)? Once again not sure about the timeline of getting letters of rec, especially in a big and busy university.

Thank you in advance for any insight!!
history.subject: Letters of Rec - How much Profs need to know you
